content.webTitle: Mauricio Pochettino full of pride for his young lions as Tottenham hit top four

fields.headline: Mauricio Pochettino full of pride for his young lions as Tottenham hit top four
fields.bodyText: Mauricio Pochettino’s eyes were twinkling but the swiftness of his interruption told plenty. It had just been put to the Tottenham manager that he had a reputation for bringing through young English players and he jumped in before the question had time to reach its point. “Only a reputation?” queried Pochettino. “I think it’s action, not reputation. I think it’s the reality.” It is certainly not hubris on his part. The figures justify Pochettino’s pride and they were augmented by what turned out to be a comfortable victory at St Mary’s, won by goals from two of the 10 England debutants to have passed under his charge. Harry Kane and Dele Alli are unlikely to benefit from more charitable defending all season but their contributions in a three-minute spell before half-time took Tottenham into the top four and the broader picture suggests they have a genuine opportunity to entrench themselves there. “We push them to be brave,” said Pochettino of a team whose average age on Saturday was 24. “It is difficult to play every game at a good level. They are very young but we are very proud of them.” Kane’s goal, his 30th of the calendar year on his 100th appearance for Tottenham, owed plenty to the courage his manager prizes. Erik Lamela and – in particular – Alli both took clatterings when moving the ball along in the buildup and the finish quietened an out-of-form Southampton team that had started brightly. The second half was an exercise in game management for the visitors and Kane believed lessons had been learned from a lax display six days previously, when Newcastle had overturned a deficit to win 2-1 at White Hart Lane. “Newcastle was probably the kick up the butt we needed,” Kane said. “We had drawn a couple of games before that too and maybe we were getting a bit complacent. That maybe woke us up a bit. This was a must-win game for us, I felt. The players knew that. Two-nil away from home at Southampton is a very good result.” The danger for Southampton is that many more offerings of this standard will make that a generous assessment. Ronald Koeman sounded worried afterwards, mentioning more than once a need to “change our mentality” after a fourth defeat in five Premier League games. Theirs was a fatal mix of the over-committed and the noncommittal when Kane ran through to open the scoring, José Fonte having dived in needlessly on Alli some 55 yards up the pitch before Virgil van Dijk, the last man between Kane and Paulo Gazzaniga, unfathomably airkicked at the ball when standing his ground should have sufficed. “We started well but then we conceded two goals and it was unacceptable,” said their midfielder, Victor Wanyama, whose own influence waned as Tottenham took control. “We were there for the first 40 minutes but then I don’t know what happened. We need to work together as a team. At the moment I don’t know what’s going on. We need to get clean sheets and score goals but at the moment it is not working for us.” Something is clearly not right and, although you do not see in Southampton’s demeanour the downing of tools that led to Garry Monk’s departure from Swansea, it would only take a poor return from their next two games – against Arsenal and West Ham – to create the kind of run that got him the sack. While Tottenham were delighted with the perceptive Kyle Walker cross that created Alli’s goal, Van Dijk had this time been overly cautious in giving him time to pick it out and the scorer, left alone in the six-yard box by Cédric Soares, could take a touch before finishing almost apologetically. Poor decisions are becoming commonplace. “I believe they have a very good squad and I think it is a negative period. It happens in every team,” said Pochettino, reliably sanguine in sentiment towards his former employers. Could they be drawn into a relegation fight? “My opinion doesn’t matter. I rate the squad and manager. There is nothing to worry about.” If that was an endorsement, it was still at some remove from the sense he emits that his own team is firmly on the right path. Man of the match Dele Alli (Tottenham)
